attributes.comment:
We are adoptive parents and hope to add to our family with additional children
someday. I am writing to STRONGLY PROTEST the proposed fee increase by
the USCIS. During our paperchase the largest obstacles we encountered were
posed by the US federal government -- the poor quality of service, the slow
response, rude employees the list is endless. For this we paid, and paid again
and paid once again when they insisted on additional fingerprints (expired -- as if I
were able to purchase new ones???), citizenship application fees (although a law
had been passed several years earlier granting automatic citizenship to my
children). Again the list is endless and too long for this forum.

Adoptive parents undergo strict scrutiny from various government and quasi
government agencies before being granted permission to parent children. We are,
in fact, the "perfect citizens" that most countries would welcome. We do not have
criminal backgrounds, pay our taxes faithfully and do not cause "problems" for our
representatives. And the thanks we get for this? Increased fees for one of the few
services we request in return for our support. The fees are already outrageous.
They would be more palatable if we received good (let's forget about excellent)
service in return. But we don't.

I strongly recommend that your agency respond to increased costs by looking at
the expense side of your budget, not the revenut. Cut your overhead, improve
your computer systems and improve your customer service. I also suggest a
division between adoption and immigration processing.

Comment on FR Doc # E7-01631
attributes.title: Comment Submitted by Sheila Woodland-McClain
